fields.label_text:
9. VASE AND COVER
FRENCH (Paris); about 1780; Marble and gilt bronze

This is one of the most sophisticated examples of gilt bronze in the collection. The delicate mounts are meticulously modelled and chased in every detail and furthermore the gilding is finished with a technique known as <u>dorure au mat</u>. It is matted by the application of salt in the final process. This produces a finish that suffuses the surface with a dull sheen and enhances the delicacy of the modelling. In contrast the plinth and berries among the ivy leaves are brilliantly burnished to a mirror-like shine.

Though the craftsmanship is of the finest quality attained in the 1780s, the <u>bronzier</u> has not been identified. Thomire supplied mounts similar in design for Sèvres after 1783, but several <u>bronziers</u> were equally capable of this workmanship at this date. A closer connection is with the dealer L. J. Maurice who supplied this sort of object at this date and who possibly supplied this vase to the Marquis de Clermont d'Amboise, who had been French ambassador in Naples and Lisbon.

Jones Collection
1144-1882

fields.descriptive_line: Black basalt vase with chased ormolu mounts
fields.physical_description: Vase of black marble with gilded metal mounts and foot. The metal foot probably from a different object.
fields.dimensions: Height: 365 mm, Width: 157 mm, Depth: 140 mm
fields.label:
9. VASE AND COVER

Jones Collection
1144-1882 [1970-1980]

fields.uncertainty: Originally attributed to France, but execution of the mounts not as refined as French production of

fields.bibliography:
Robiquet, Jacques. <u>Gouthière, sa vie, son oeuvre: essai de catalogue raisonné</u>. Bibliothèque d'érudition artistique. Paris: Renouard, H. Laurens, 1912
See p. 175, where Robiquet attributes the vase to Gouthière.
Smith, Cecil H. Victoria and Albert Museum. <u>Catalogue of the Jones Collection, Part II: Ceramics, Ormolu, Goldsmiths' Work, Enamels, Sculpture, Tapestry, Books, and Prints</u>. London: The Authority of the Board of Education, 1924.
Attributes the ormolu mounts to Gouthière and suggests the design of the mounts is 'probably after ... Dugourc'.
fields.history_note: The workmanship of the gilded metal mounts on this vase has been associated with the hand of one of the finest French bronze-casters and gilders, Pierre Gouthière. However, recent examination of the piece has shown up some troubling inconsistencies in design and function. The metal foot is unlikely to have been made originally for this vase. It is too small and insubstantial to support its weight, and there are signs it has been padded out to accommodate the load. Moreover the ornament on the foot, associated with military victory (the feet of lions, oak leaves) bears no relation to the ornament on the vase itself (ivy, an owl) which is associated with mourning and night.
